Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism of superinfection exclusion by an RNA virus

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study how cells infected by one virus become resistant to a secondary infection by the same or closely related virus. This process, called superinfection exclusion (SIE), is used by many viruses, including important pathogens of humans, animals, and plants; it plays an important role in the pathogenesis and evolution of viral populations and has clear implications for treating viral infections. For instance, in plants, purposeful inoculation with a harmless virus strain can be used to protect plants from infection by related pathogenic viruses. In spite of its significance, the phenomenon of SIE is not well understood. Thus, elucidation of the SIE mechanism(s) should have broad scientific impact by providing a necessary foundation for development of new strategies to control viral diseases of humans and economically important agricultural crops. The research will also have strong educational impact by offering training opportunities for postdoctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students and by developing tools that can be used for promoting STEM learning by younger students.

This research project aims to elucidate the mechanism of SIE of Citrus tristeza virus (CTV), a member of the family Closteroviridae, which includes the largest and most complex positive-strand RNA viruses of higher plants. CTV represents a valuable model system for studying SIE, due to the existence of numerous well-characterized isolates with distinctive genetic characteristics. Furthermore, CTV provides a possibility for studying this phenomenon at the whole organism level. The project builds on observations suggesting that SIE by CTV operates by a unique mechanism, which involves multiple virus-encoded factors. Advanced genetic tools will be combined with innovative techniques and ultrastructural approaches for studying protein-protein and RNA-protein interactions. Materials and data produced by the project will be openly accessible for research and educational uses. For example, the fluorescently-tagged viruses used as part of the research enable visualization of virus movement in infected trees and thus serve as an excellent learning tool for engaging young students. Taken together, the results of the research are expected to produce new insights into the mechanism of SIE by CTV, as well as to advance understanding of virus-host interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. This project examines virus-virus and virus-host interactions mediating viral superinfection exclusion (SIE). SIE or homologous interference, a phenomenon in which a primary viral infection prevents a secondary infection with the same or closely-related virus, has been observed commonly for viruses in various systems, including important pathogens of humans, animals, and plants. SIE limits replication of two closely related viruses in the same cell and/or host and, thus, affects viral pathogenesis and evolution of virus populations. We are using Citrus tristeza virus (CTV), a large RNA virus, as a model to study SIE. This project was focused on the identification and characterization of the viral factors involved in CTV SIE. In this work, using support from NSF, we made a number of important discoveries that markedly advanced our understanding of CTV SIE and the CTV biology and pathogenesis, in general. We showed that CTV SIE is a powerful virus-controlled function that completely prevents superinfection by a homologous virus from the same virus strain and is mediated by multiple viral factors. One of them is the viral p33 protein. Lack of the functional p33 completely eliminates the ability of the virus to exclude superinfection by the same or closely related virus. Further characterization of p33 demonstrated that this non-conserved membrane-associated protein (i) plays a role of a viral effector that interacts with plant immunity and modulates host response to virus infection; (ii) mediates the effective virus movement in the plant hosts; (iii) interacts with three other proteins of CTV, which function as suppressors of host RNA silencing; (iv) specifically binds a viral non-coding RNA LMT1 produced from the 5’-terminal region of the CTV genome, which is the second determinant of CTV SIE. We next showed that the latter RNA molecule is crucial for CTV infection. LMT1 counteracts the host response against the invading virus by subverting the phytohormone-mediated plant defense. Collectively, our data indicate that CTV SIE could not be explained by the mechanisms described previously for other viruses and suggest a novel mechanism for SIE between virus variants that appears to involve the viral p33 protein and the 5’ region that encodes RNA LMT1, both of which have multiple functions in the virus infection cycle. We believe that further understanding of SIE by CTV may open up new avenues to manage virus diseases.

Broader impacts. Examination of the interaction and exclusion between virus variants significantly improves our understanding of how virus populations are formed and evolve. Such knowledge is crucial for building a necessary foundation for the development of novel therapeutics to mitigate viral diseases in the fields of medicine and agriculture. We believe that understanding of the mechanism of the CTV SIE phenomenon can lead to the development of new effective strategies to control diseases caused by this group of viruses and possibly by viruses from other taxonomic groups. From the educational standpoint, this project provided excellent educational and training opportunities for raising scientists. Several undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers have been trained in multiple molecular and cellular biology techniques, including cloning into a full-length cDNA clone of such a large and complex virus as CTV, which genome encompasses almost 20 kb. Additionally, the project provided opportunities of science exposure for K-12 students and for teacher training. The research results were broadly disseminated via publishing in the leading peer-reviewed journals and presentations at the national and international scientific meetings.
